trans-unit.source: Controls how a document is printed, when printing from a Windows Forms application.
When implemented in a derived class, PrintController controls how a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> is printed.

<xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.Print%2A?displayProperty=fullName> invokes the print controller's <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPrint%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPage%2A>, and <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPage%2A> methods, which in turn tell the printer how to print the document.
Print preview uses a specialized PrintController.
For an example of a print controller that is specialized for print preview, see the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PreviewPrintController>.
PrintController is used by <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument>, and not typically used directly.
The .NET Framework includes three print controllers that are derived from PrintController that help accomplish common tasks.
The <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.StandardPrintController> prints a document to a printer.

The <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PreviewPrintController> generates a preview of what the document will look like when printed and is used by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintPreviewControl> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintPreviewDialog> classes.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> provides a printing status dialog during the printing process.
For more information about printing with Windows Forms, see the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing> namespace overview.
If you wish to print from a Windows Presentation Foundation application, see the <xref:System.Printing> namespace.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController"></xref> class.
Gets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController"></xref> is used for print preview.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> in all cases.
When overridden in a derived class, completes the control sequence that determines when and how to print a page of a document.
OnEndPage is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event.
If an exception is thrown inside a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event of a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument>, OnEndPage is not called.
<xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A> creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> that is sent to the printer.

After <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> to a graphic of a single page.
(Use the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPage%2A> method to set how to print a page in a document.

For example, you can adjust page settings separately for each page.) The OnEndPage method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics>, while the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintPageEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
When overridden in a derived class, completes the control sequence that determines when and how to print a document.
OnEndPrint is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.EndPrint> event.
<xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A> creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> that is sent to the printer.

After <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> to a graphic of a single page.
(Use the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A> method to determine when and how to print a document.

For example, you can delay printing for 30 minutes or adjust the printer settings for the document.) The <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics>, while the OnEndPrint method deallocates the object.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
When overridden in a derived class, begins the control sequence that determines when and how to print a page of a document.
OnStartPage is called immediately before the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event.
<xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A> creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> that is sent to the printer.
After <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the OnStartPage method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> to a graphic of a single page.

The <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics>, while the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
Use the OnStartPage method to set how to print a page in a document.
For example, you can adjust page settings separately for each page.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintPageEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Graphics"></xref> that represents a page from a <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref>.
When overridden in a derived class, begins the control sequence that determines when and how to print a document.
OnStartPrint is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.BeginPrint> event.
Use the OnStartPrint method to determine when and how to print a document.
For example, you can delay printing for 30 minutes or adjust the printer settings for the document.
OnStartPrint creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> that is sent to the printer.
After OnStartPrint is called, the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> to one of a single page.

The <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics>, while the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
The OnStartPrint method is a good place to verify that <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings> are valid.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
